content:
I've just edited the statement:

Goal
* Formatted all variables and constants.

Input
* Formatted the variable "speed".

* Formatted the constants "a" and "b", and replaced "..." with "and so on".

* Added the variable name "r" for radius for consistency with the Constraints section.

Output
* First line: Added the word "integer".

* Changed "Last [[n+1]]" to "Next [[n]]+1".

Constraints
* Deleted the last constraint:
The output angles are always {{integers}}

Stub generator
* Changed "bends" to "r" for consistency with the Constraints section.
https://forum.codingame.com/t/community-puzzle-stall-tilt/107550/26
Edited to fix the units (speed in m/s, not m.s, acceleration in m/sÂ²) and the output description (n+1 lines as you have to add yourself "y" in it, which is btw completely artificial, yet whatever).

I approved because it ticks the marks, but you ought to be aware (and possibly fix):
- That's not counter-steering. That's not even steering. It's simple centripetal tilt.
- Not sure you actually mean "stall" here. Maybe slip or just fall?
- Why the 60 speed limit? It seems neither relevant nor tested.

The ambiguity resolves, but the phrasing is unnecessarily vague: when you say "b falls first", you ought to specify if you mean time or bends.

(Also, your specs allow N=12, but your code would break)
Maybe you want to add tag "Sorting" ?
Suggestion to mention that, the config of the test example will ensure there's only 1 unique output.
It says the "3rd line" and "4th line", but the actual input are multiple lines?

Hi, good puzzle. One problem though : when riders have the same speed, there is no way to order them. Finishing the race or falling on the same bend, which one is ranked better then the other ? I found this issue on the first validator, e and k both drive at 42 m.s (I did not check if other tests / validators are impacted).

Hi there, nice idea.

But actually the "input/output" part is badly written. 
The First line: Number n of motorcycles (other than yours) participating in the competition
The Second line: Number v of CURVES in the circuit
NEXT n LINES: The constant speed of each motorcycle (The first speed of the list given by the loop is that of competitor a, the second that of competitor b....) (m.s)
NEXT v LINES: The radius of each curve of the circuit (m)

Output
The First line: The maximum constant speed to avoid stalling in the circuit.
LAST n LINES : The ranking of the competition

on your output instructions you said "first line...." then said "last line" but you forgot the other bunch of outputs, but I'm not going to edit because I'm just confused with the ranking as to why "y" is always in first place but at the same time another person gets rank A, plus maybe I'm just missing something accidentally and patience is key anyway :)
Of course, you can vote "DOWNVOTE" but can you justify with a comment, please. In order to make this space constructive and to improve this puzzle so that it is pleasant for everyone.

Hello, thanks to Razovsky's advice I was able to modify the information: Input and Output. Perhaps this time the statement will seem clearer to you. Finally, you say that you don't understand for "y" in the first position, the letter "y" represents your position in the ranking and since the main goal is to give your bike the most efficient speed without an accident then you will necessarily be the winner of the competition. Thank you for your comment, hoping to have helped you.
Thank you for your comment, indeed I am not a great literary person and moreover, I am not very comfortable with the English language. I'm going to apply your advice right now.

Hi, I thank you for your support, it's an excellent point you just made. In reality, I didn't want to create equality (because in reality there is always a way to decide between them), but this is a mistake on my part and I will try to correct it instead. Thank you again for your contribution.
Hi, this problem has already been fixed thanks anyway for your comment
(and, honestly, there's no physics left in the puzzle)
Hi, even if it's still quite superficial, you're absolutely right to say so. Thank you for your contribution.
Edited to fix the constraints, cf https://forum.codingame.com/t/community-puzzle-stall-tilt/107550/18
Thank you, and sorry for the inconvenience.

This has indeed nothing to do with counter-steering.
@Magicien-d-oz Instead of mentioning techniques that are unrelated to the problem, you could mention that finding the limit speed for each bend is at the heart of this sport: The current MotoGP champion Marc Marquez is also the rider who falls the most (paradoxically).

Hi, I thank you for your comment, but on some points, our opinions differ:
-When I passed my motorcycle licence, the term countersteering was used in this case (I think your name is a scientific name, I prefer the name most often)
-It seems to me that the term stall is appropriate, I wanted to designate the non-stick of the wheel on the road when the speed is too high.
(Of course, I can be wrong. I wouldn't pretend to say that everything I say is true, if you keep your ideas you can always come and talk to me in private)
-On the other hand, I agree with you on my inaccuracy in terms of turns and falls, I will correct it right away.
-Finally, I put speed<60 so that the values are not too far away to see if the classification system is effective.
Here's if you have any more questions, don't hesitate, hoping you've answered everything.
Changing "counter steering" to "cetripetal tilt".
